text: Wilt not thou, O God, who hast cast us off? and wilt not thou, O God, go forth with our hosts?
text_kjv: Wilt not thou, O God, who hast cast us off? and wilt not thou, O God, go forth with our hosts?
text_niv: Is it not you, O God, you who have rejected usand no longer go out with our armies?
text_esv: Have you not rejected us, O God? You do not go out, O God, with our armies.
text_nlt: Have you rejected us, O God?Will you no longer march with our armies?
text_msg: You aren't giving up on us, are you, God?refusing to go out with our troops?
text_nasb: Have not You Yourself, O God, rejected us? And will You not go forth with our armies, O God?
context: Psalm 108 is a composite psalm, drawing heavily from Psalm 57:7-11 and Psalm 60:5-12. Understanding its historical context requires looking at the circumstances that may have prompted Psalms 57 and 60. While the superscriptions attribute these psalms to David, the exact historical situation is debated. Psalm 57 is described as being written when David fled from Saul in the cave. This evokes a time of intense personal distress and reliance on God's protection. Psalm 60, on the other hand, seems to refer to a national crisis involving military setbacks against Aram Naharaim and Aram Zobah, possibly compounded by Edomite incursions. These were powerful kingdoms that challenged Israel's nascent power. The phrase 'cast us off' in Psalm 108:11 directly echoes Psalm 60:1 and 60:10, suggesting a period where Israel experienced defeat and perceived abandonment by God. Military campaigns in the ancient Near East were often viewed as direct manifestations of divine favor or disfavor. Defeats were interpreted as signs that the national god had turned away from his people. The request for God to 'go forth with our hosts' was a common plea before battle. It was believed that the presence of the divine warrior, Yahweh, ensured victory. Kings often carried sacred objects or sought prophetic pronouncements to guarantee divine assistance. The psalm's use of these earlier texts suggests a deliberate act of remembering past struggles and reaffirming faith in God's power to deliver despite present circumstances. It is a plea for renewed divine intervention in a time of perceived national crisis.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 108:11 is a powerful expression of the complex relationship between God and His people. The opening question, "Wilt not thou, O God, who hast cast us off?" acknowledges a past experience of divine abandonment. This 'casting off' doesn't necessarily imply a permanent rejection but rather a temporary withdrawal of favor, perhaps as a consequence of sin or as a test of faith. It speaks to the reality that even chosen people experience times when God seems distant or inactive. This verse reflects the Deuteronomic theology, where obedience brings blessing and disobedience brings curses. The question isn't accusatory but rather a desperate plea for understanding and restoration. It confronts God with the apparent contradiction between His covenant promises and the current experience of defeat. The second part of the verse, "and wilt not thou, O God, go forth with our hosts?" is a prayer for renewed divine intervention. It invokes the image of God as a warrior, a powerful protector who leads His people into battle. This reflects the concept of Yahweh Sabaoth, the Lord of Hosts, a God whose power is manifested in military victory. The psalmist recognizes that human strength alone is insufficient to overcome their enemies. They acknowledge their dependence on God's supernatural assistance. The phrase 'go forth with our hosts' suggests a desire for God's active participation, not just passive observation. Itâ€™s a plea for God to reclaim His position as the defender of Israel and to demonstrate His power to the nations. The verse embodies a tension between acknowledging divine judgment and clinging to hope in divine mercy and restoration. It underscores the persistent belief that even in times of seeming abandonment, God remains sovereign and capable of delivering His people.
application: Psalm 108:11 holds profound relevance for modern believers grappling with personal or collective challenges. The feeling of being 'cast off' by God is a universal experience, whether due to personal sin, difficult circumstances, or unanswered prayers. This verse reminds us that acknowledging these feelings is not necessarily a sign of weak faith, but rather an honest expression of our humanity before a God who understands our struggles. The key is to move from lament to petition, as the psalmist does. When facing adversity, we can emulate the psalmist by first acknowledging our feelings of abandonment to God, without sugarcoating our doubts or fears. It is a recognition that bad things happen, and sometimes it *feels* like God isn't there. Then, we must actively choose to remember God's past faithfulness and His promises, clinging to the hope that He will ultimately work all things for good. The plea for God to 'go forth with our hosts' can be interpreted as a call to seek God's guidance and empowerment in our endeavors. This means seeking His wisdom through prayer, scripture study, and wise counsel before making decisions or pursuing goals. It means aligning our actions with His will and relying on His strength to overcome obstacles. 'Our hosts' in the modern context can refer to our efforts, our resources, our skills, and our communities. We are called to invite God's presence into all aspects of our lives, recognizing that our own efforts are insufficient without His blessing. Furthermore, this verse encourages us to advocate for justice and righteousness in our world, standing against oppression and working for the betterment of society. We can ask God to 'go forth' with our efforts to combat injustice, to heal the brokenhearted, and to spread the Gospel. Ultimately, Psalm 108:11 is a call to unwavering faith in the face of adversity, reminding us that even when we feel abandoned, God remains sovereign and capable of delivering us.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you today with a heart both hopeful and heavy. There are times, Lord, when I feel like I have been cast off, abandoned to face life's challenges alone. I confess that doubt and fear creep in, and I question your presence in my life. Forgive me for my lack of faith during these difficult moments. I choose now to remember your faithfulness in the past, your unwavering love and protection. I ask you, Lord, to go forth with my endeavors, to guide my steps, and to empower me with your Holy Spirit. Strengthen my resolve to overcome obstacles and to pursue your will for my life. I entrust my worries and my fears into your loving hands. Help me to trust in your perfect timing and your unfailing love. I pray for those who are struggling with feelings of abandonment today. Comfort them, Lord, and remind them of your constant presence. In Jesus' name, I pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: No, 'cast us off' does not necessarily imply permanent abandonment. It often signifies a temporary withdrawal of favor or a period of testing, intended to refine and strengthen faith. God's covenant with His people remains, offering hope for restoration.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Does 'cast us off' mean God has abandoned us permanently?

faqs.answer: It means asking for God's active participation and blessing in our endeavors. It's a plea for divine guidance, protection, and empowerment, recognizing that our efforts are insufficient without His involvement.
faqs.question: Q2: What does it mean for God to 'go forth with our hosts'?

faqs.answer: Acknowledge your feelings of abandonment to God honestly, remember His past faithfulness, and seek His guidance and empowerment in your efforts. Trust that even in difficult times, God is working for your good.
faqs.question: Q3: How can I apply this verse when facing personal struggles?

faqs.answer: Yes, it is acceptable to express your doubts and fears to God. He understands our human limitations and welcomes honest communication. The key is to move from questioning to seeking understanding and trusting in His plan.
faqs.question: Q4: Is it acceptable to question God when feeling 'cast off'?

faqs.answer: Yes, in a modern context, 'hosts' can refer to various aspects of our lives, including our efforts, resources, skills, communities, and endeavors. We invite God into those efforts.
